parts.text:
```json
{
"application": "Slurm",
"details": {
"scheduler": "Slurm",
"spack": {
"version": "0.17.3",
"instance": "gpu",
"instance_dir": "${HOME}/cm/shared/apps/spack/0.17.3/gpu",
"package": "fftw@3.3.10",
"compiler": "intel@19.1.1.217",
"variants": "~mpi ~openmp ~pfft_patches",
"dependencies": ""
},
"intel_license_file": "40000@elprado.sdsc.edu:40200@elprado.sdsc.edu",
"resources": {
"nodes": 1,
"tasks_per_node": 1,
"cpus_per_task": 10,
"memory": "93G",
"gpus": 1,
"time": "00:30:00"
},
"other_software": {
"hdf5": "1.10.7"
}
}
```

This script is running on a Slurm cluster. It uses the Slurm workload manager to submit jobs and manage resources. The script utilizes Spack, a package manager for scientific software, to install FFTW (Fast Fourier Transform in the West). It leverages the Intel compiler and specifies various flags and dependencies for the installation. 

The script also utilizes a module system, likely Lmod, for managing software environments. It defines several environment variables, including `SPACK_VERSION`, `SPACK_INSTANCE_NAME`, and `SPACK_PACKAGE`, to configure the Spack installation.

The script also demonstrates the use of the `sbatch` command to submit subsequent jobs (in this case, a job to install HDF5) with a dependency on the current job's successful completion. 

Finally, the script includes a `sleep` command for pausing execution. This could be for various reasons, like allowing time for a process to complete or waiting for another job to finish before proceeding.
